entry.title: Hitting my limit on the Howe Sound Crest Trail
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ St Marks, ‚úÖ Unneccessary, ‚úÖ North Unneccessary, ‚úÖ Thomas, ‚úÖ James, ‚úÖ David

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

I üíö hiking and the back country, camping and being out in nature. I like mountains and I‚Äôve hiked lots of them. But I don‚Äôt like mountaineering in the sense of requiring vertical climbing, vertical drops, rock climbing etc. I‚Äôve tried outdoors climbing and it just scared me, I just have a real fear of vertical drops. For the majority of hikes I‚Äôve done this has never been a problem. There‚Äôs the odd moment on mountains I didn‚Äôt like, but that‚Äôs rare.

And then I did the Howe Sound Crest trail.

This day enabled me to bag 6 peaks but completely destroyed me physically and pretty much wrecked me mentally too, I hit my limit. Between Unnecessary the other side of James Peak there was so much scrambly, vertical stuff that it scared the crap out of me. There‚Äôs the traverse around the West Lion, Thomas Peak, ridge walk up James Peak and then the traverse between James peaks. There are parts with vertical cliffs on both sides, sometimes just one side, sometimes inches away. Sometimes you are scrambling down rough rocks, roots and dirts towards instant death on cliffs. There are multiple places where a mis-step won‚Äôt just result in scratches, cuts or hurt limb, but just straight death.

Many people do these trails and have no problem. This is likely just my problem. Some even love big drops and you‚Äôll see them grinning on pictures. I don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs not just the medical problems I‚Äôve had like inner ear vertigo type problems, I just can‚Äôt do it. Howe Sound Crest Trail pushed me over my limit and I was just terrified at points.

I was going to do the whole trail, but in the end found the quickest way off the trail when I realised it was just getting worse and went down into Lions Bay instead of camping. Of course, I‚Äôd done all the hard and scary parts and could have just continued, but I understood I was in a bad state and could not face anything else that day.

I understood that my problems aren‚Äôt shared and went back to read resources to check I wasn‚Äôt missing something. The Glorious Mountains of the North Shore says things like ‚ÄúThere is no real exposure, but there exists the possibility for a fall and an injury.‚Äù and ‚ÄúJust take it calm and slow‚Äù and ‚ÄúTake care when approaching‚Ä¶ a fall to the west would be fatal‚Äù. I like this book a lot, but for me the danger felt much worse and much more stressful than was presented. The Howe Sound Crest trail is number 2 in trails for search and rescue according to this list (actually this was a pretty accurate depiction).

Anyways, it‚Äôs done I‚Äôll never go back and I can now definitely start crossing off mountains I will never, ever do. I‚Äôm no longer sure I‚Äôll do all the peaks on the North Shore or even want to do this anymore, we‚Äôll see.

entry.title: Goat Mountain, Goat Ridge Peak
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Goat Mountain, ‚úÖ Goat Ridge Peak

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

Goat Mountain is relatively straightforward, but has very steep paths up it. Some of those steep parts have chains, others do not.

From there it‚Äôs a hike around the ridge to Goat Ridge Peak. This is through heather, blueberry bushes and small trees, with many patches of snow causing streams and waterfalls. This is one of the most beautiful hikes I‚Äôve done this year with absolutely amazing views. Would recommend.

But I wasn‚Äôt alone. With clear and recent bear footprints in the snow and the mud. Not surprising given the number of blueberry bushes that will be perfect bear food soon.

What started out as a relatively easy hike, soon turned into something that I struggled with. My heart rate was climbing fast, I was tired and felt more wiped than I have in a long time. The feeling was similar to when I struggled on Mt Frosty.

The hike across the peak is very exposed and I was in the mid-day sun at that point for quite a while, working my way across snow. I was tired, dehydrated and had lost a lot of electrolytes which I hadn‚Äôt replaced.

Then I pulled a muscle climbing down some quite vertical sections.

By the time I got back to the gondola I was thoroughly drained and tired. Currently I‚Äôm doubting if I can actually complete my goal, not only are some peaks really hard (and look very intimidating from up high), but I really questioned by fitness today. At this point I think I‚Äôm gonna have to make doing all the peaks a 2024 and 2025 goal.

entry.title: Silver Star, Mt. Fromme
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Mount Fromme

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

On the weekend I was in Silver Star resort, so did some hiking on Silver Star Mountain. These aren‚Äôt peaks on the North Shore, but it was nice to do something different. We hiked up over Silver Star, down into the provincial park and then back around the hill.

It was hot and the hike up was surrounded with lovely wildflowers. Going into the provincial park side wasn‚Äôt much to speak of, long trails with no people, no views, trees on every side, boggy and with bugs. The Black Prince cabin was neat though. Overall it was nice to get a lot of kms on new boots and it was pretty and sunny.

Given that Silver Star hiking trails are very few, since its mostly for mountain bikers, and then they charge you to hike - I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it as a hiker.

Today I did Fromme, which is a peak for the peak baggers list. We went down from the Gondola, then up pipeline pass and up to the top of the mountain. Then all the way down to Skyline road.

Overall I really liked Fromme, not too long and steep. A nice flat top to relax on and (mostly) a nice gentle downhill. Would recommend as a nice day hike for most people. It was also really cool to see good views of all the other mountains I‚Äôll be doing as well üòé

entry.title: Grouse, Dam and Little Goat
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Grouse ‚úÖ Dam ‚úÖ Little Goat

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

These are three of the easier peaks on the North Shore, being close to the top of the gondola. Which I took up, making for a relatively easy day. It wasn‚Äôt raining and when the skies momentarily cleared was quite warm.

The snow hasn‚Äôt melted and after Dam it was continuous snow with some parts of the trail hard to make out, due to the lack of tape and flagging in the trees. The clouds cleared momentarily for nice views of Goat and Kennedy Lake, but those views were brief.

Getting back to the gondola I found out it had broken down. Looking at the queue size and number of people, I figured it would be several trips before I could get on the gondola so may as well do the BCMC down.

The gondola wasn‚Äôt fixed until that evening, meaning that apparently many people ill-equipped and not physically able to do the trail were taking it down in the evening. It‚Äôs a slippery trail and so there were many first responders out to help. I was on the bus home by that point, but that sounds like a tough day for many.

entry.title: Mount Strachan
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Mount Strachan

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

Saturday we headed up Mount Strachan. This is a pretty easy hike, but again at about 1,100m elevation we hit snow and ice. We were able to keep going, but it was inconsistent snow and bare rock - making spikes hard to use on my feet.

In the end we just gave up and hiked the ski runs up and down, boring but got the job done.

We got to the peak, but the true peak (10m higher) was looking rather scary, with very steep up and downs on invisible trails across treacherous snow. At this point, like everyone else we encountered that day, we decided not to go for the other peak and turn back from the true peak.

It‚Äôs one of those weekends where I had grand plans of more peaks and they didn‚Äôt happen.

Damn.

entry.title: A backpack
entry.content:
In recent years I‚Äôve upgraded some of my gear as I get more into backpacking, with things like a new tent, sleeping bag and so on. One thing I hadn‚Äôt done was look seriously at my backpack which I‚Äôd just bought at MEC for a trip around Europe because it seemed ok. I was thinking I needed something lighter and more comfortable. So I went to Valhalla Pure Outfitters (there‚Äôs one in North Vancouver now) and one of my old running mates works there and was able to give me some great detailed advice. And here‚Äôs what I got: the Osprey Talon Velocity 30L and I üíö it.

There‚Äôs attention to detail on this pack that I‚Äôve not seen on any of my other bags. All the straps have bits to stop them flapping. The side pockets can be accessed from the top and side - its easy to reach around and grab something without taking it off. The front straps are wide meaning its comfortable against my body.

Most importantly, this backpack is well fitting and barely feels like I‚Äôm carrying any weight at all. The slim but tall profile means that my centre of gravity is close to be body. Weight is well distributed onto my hips. Honestly a lot of time it feels like I‚Äôm barely carrying any weight. I‚Äôve done multiple 5+ hour hikes with it so far and haven‚Äôt really noticed the weight.

There‚Äôs enough space that I can carry all my day gear, the ten essentials, all my overnight gear and spare clothes and food in it with ease. It has been a game changer. It turns out it‚Äôs not super light at 990g (but that‚Äôs 160g lighter than my last) but it‚Äôs so well designed and comfortable, I can‚Äôt imagine wanting anything else at this point.

This has enabled me to easily carry emergency overnight gear on all my hikes, without any penalty. Even if I don‚Äôt plan on staying overnight, I can now comfortably hike the North Shore knowing that if a problem occurs, or I just run out of light, I can just settle in for the night and resume my hike the next day. That feels like the safest way to hike and that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm really happy with this pack.

This now means I‚Äôve got:

  • A small 5L Salomon running pack for runs.
  • A small 10L Salomon running pack for day hikes.
  • A 30L Osprey backpack for long hikes or a few days of backpacking.
  • A 40L MEC backpack for longer backpacking trips.
  • A 65L Arcteryx monster backpack for when I want to carry the world and hate myself.

entry.title: Pump Peak, Suicide Bluffs and Hollyburn
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Pump Pake ‚úÖ Suicide Bluffs ‚úÖ Hollyburn

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

The wet and snowy conditions on the mountains persist and this is making some bigger mountains challenging. At this time of year the snow is slippery and in the process of melting, it can be dangerous. On Saturday I went through the snow and fell into a rock and have many bruises, I got off easy.

Saturday was an attempt to do Pump Peak and maybe beyond, but the snow was consistent and deep all the way from the base of the Brockton chair lift. At that point I put my spikes on, got my poles out and kept them out all the way up and back.

At the top when I got there (in the morning) there was very little visibility and over 1m+ deep snow still covering everything but the most exposed rocks. The weather was bad and I did not fancy trying to do Tim Jones Peak or Mount Seymour - those are on the way if you do Runners Peak or Elsay anyways.

On the way back I decided to do Suicide Bluffs and then looped around to Dog Mountain. The snow had mostly cleared at this elevation and the trail was easy to follow. The weather lifted for a bit, there was even the odd bit of sun and some stunning views.

Sunday was Hollyburn was snowy. And I was snowed on and rained on and cold. It was like a hike in December, not the middle of June.

Most of the way down I was wondering if I‚Äôd chosen the wrong year to track and bag so many peaks. July to September is going to be busy.

Note: I‚Äôve removed peaks below 1,000m on Gambier, Anvil and Bowen (apart from the one I did) because they just don‚Äôt interest me. Others might do them but I won‚Äôt be.

entry.title: Vancouver Python User Group Changes
entry.content:
Summary: Meetup is increasing prices so the costs for the Python User Group will be over $700 CAD a year. We are closing our Meetup account and moving to GitHub before July 7th 2024.

What do we need?

We need somewhere to organise activities and talks, announce events and communicate with the community. These are pretty simple and straightforward requirements. We‚Äôve actually been doing a bunch of these things using GitHub anyway.

Why not Meetup?

Meetup has been costing it‚Äôs organisers about $37 CAD a month for ages and has just increased it‚Äôs price to over $60 CAD a month. The minimal functionality Meetup provides is not worth it. This was not optional price raise, there was no grandfathering in of old Meetups.

When talking to the former organizer Bryan Chow about this, he resisted moving off Meetup and saving himself money because of how hard it is get off of Meetup. Since we can‚Äôt get an export of emails out of Meetup, we know that any shift to a new platform will cost us users, probably most of it.

A price rise of that amount for features that suck or should be free is unacceptable. Plus, I‚Äôm retiring and don‚Äôt want to spend my money on Meetup. It also means it‚Äôs really hard to either get anyone else to run it - no-one wants to take on this money.

Also, here‚Äôs the first question Meetup asks when I decide to cancel:

No - fuck you Meetup. That‚Äôs not what this community is about. So just to be clear I will never charge people to come to a simple Python meetup.

Why GitHub?

It‚Äôs free and it will be for a long time yet. It does all the things we need. Everyone has an account there.

We will lose people, we will lose visibility and I think pretty much anyone else can take over the old group on Meetup. It‚Äôs like Meetup is holding us hostage.

What next?

Go to vancouver/vanpy and click on the Watch button:

Then select All activity:

If you get a lot of GitHub notifications, this might be a chance to try prioritizing your notifications

On Mastodon follow the @vanpy account.

That‚Äôs it.

The Python Software Foundation

The PSF has a grant program to get Meetup costs paid for. I applied for that in November 2023 (yep 8 months ago) and still haven‚Äôt been added into the PSF program. At the last discord Q&A I think I heard that the person who as able to do this was on holiday (or something like that). I‚Äôm sorry for other user groups in this situation.

I‚Äôm not sure what‚Äôs happened there with the PSF grants program but I‚Äôm not gonna keep waiting for whatever is happening to sort itself out. Perhaps there‚Äôs better places for the PSF grants than funding Meetup.

Note: I have charged for conferences, but those are big and require money to put on.

entry.title: de Pencier and Black
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ de Pencier ‚úÖ Black Mountain

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

On Saturday I did De Pencier by hiking all the way up from Deep Cove. I could have done it from the parking lot, but it‚Äôs a good practice hike and I was able to get a ride back down, so may as well take the opportunity.

It‚Äôs currently snow free up to about 950m. Snow is common in shaded areas over 1000m and is constant in shaded areas over 1050m. Around Mystery Lake, Brockton chair and De Pencier itself is still snowy and spikes highly recommended.

On Sunday I did Black Mountain from the Cypress parking lot. A shorter hike with my sore legs was most welcome. There were some patches of snow in shaded areas, but spikes weren‚Äôt needed and it was mostly clear. On the top of Black Mountain there was no snow.

On both hikes any snow in exposed areas was rapidly melting.

entry.title: Mt Gardner
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Mt. Gardner ‚ùå Suicide Bluffs ‚ùå de Pencier

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

On Saturday with a couple of friends we did Mt. Gardner on Bowen Island. It‚Äôs one of the lower peaks and guaranteed to be snow free. We hopped on the ferry, parked at the south west end and then went up the hike.

Honestly it‚Äôs a pretty straightforward hike, a few steep parts. At the top the true summit is pretty rubbish, so head north to the telecommunication towers for a better view. All we saw was mist and cloud as the weather closed in. We hiked all the way down in the rain which of course stopped, right as we completed the hike.

On Sunday I aimed to do Suicide Bluffs and de Pencier. I figured at 1,100m odd they‚Äôd be snow free or at least less snow, especially considering my experience on South Needle (similar elevation) the week before. How different it was. About 15 minutes after leaving the parking lot, we were facing continual snow and had our spikes on.

Suicide bluffs trail was deep snow, something we were not prepared for. There‚Äôs no trail visible, no markings and without snow shoes we were getting very wet. We turned back quite quickly, not wanting to venture anywhere near unstable snow or cornices. We then thought about de Pencier so headed over that way and faced similar deep snow.

At this point it started raining and was cold. So knowing that these peaks are something I do regularly during the summer and will come back to, decided to call it quits. A little disappointing, but the amount of snow still up there was surprising. Going to be another couple of weeks before those are easy to do.

entry.title: Hike - South Needle via Lynn Peak
entry.content:
Bagged: ‚úÖ Lynn Peak ‚úÖ Rice Peak ‚úÖ South Needle

‚ÑπÔ∏è List of 2024 peaks bagged.

Instead of aiming for more bike races or longer runs, this year I‚Äôve set my sights somewhere slightly different. Instead I‚Äôm going to try and bag all the peaks in North Vancouver, as defined by the Peak Baggers group. Unfortunately that group requires Facebook and I refuse to use that site so I‚Äôve got my own list going. It‚Äôs a big list.

It‚Äôs still early in the year for any of the higher North or West Vancouver peaks. Most people are doing Gambier, Bowen and Anvil. Those are hills I might do at some point, but don‚Äôt really interest me as much as the big ones on the mainland. So I thought yesterday I‚Äôd take a stab at the Needles in Lynn Valley, because they are lower than most of the other peaks and aren‚Äôt as likely to be covered in snow and ice. I tried to get to South Needle last year and was turned around by snow and ice that made it really hard to hike.

This year, getting up to the first couple of peaks was relatively straightforward and there wasn‚Äôt any snow. Between those peaks and the South Needle there were patches of snow but nothing too bad and up to the South Needle at 1163m. The hike there is great, at times you are walking on tree lined ridge with huge tree lined steep slopes on each side. The trail has really steep parts and there was just one bit on the South Needle where my nervousness with heights hit me - a small rock outcropping with a 100% chance of death if you slip.

At the top the north side and the Middle Needle was all snow and ice covered. I met a group up there who tried to go towards Middle Needle and saw the steep slope with big drops covered in snow, ice, all in various stages of melting and turned back. They had better gear than me (I just had crampons) so I knew that was not going to happen.

On the way down, I went down the Hydraulic Creek trail, which is really steep. Just looking at the elevation change on Strava üëÜ makes this clear.

Then it was either back out along the road through the Seymour Demonstration Forest, or even further by heading over to Fishermans Trail and coming out at the top of Riverside drive. I‚Äôve run and cycled that trail a lot and forgotten how boring and long it was.

An amazing hike with amazing views, it was a shame I couldn‚Äôt get the other two needles in but I can get those from the Coliseum mountain side another time.

So there it goes, my first attempt at trying to bag all the peaks with a couple of relatively easy ones. Let‚Äôs see how it goes!

entry.title: Trip - Joshua Tree
entry.content:
In my new job I had five days of vacation to spend by the end of the year. So I took a week and went to Palm Springs and then to Joshua Tree with a friend. The original plan was a few days in Joshua Tree National Park followed by a day or two in Mojave Desert with overnights each way in Palm Springs.

A few days before leaving we were trudging knee deep through snow at the top of Mount Seymour in North Vancouver. This trip turned out to be quite a contrast.

For this trip I made a couple of additions to my gear because I was concerned about night time temperatures for camping which drop below zero.

  • I finally got a puffy style jacket to keep me warm, I‚Äôve seen these on a bunch of trails and always thought they were a bit weird, preferring layers instead. Would recommend.
  • I got a sleeping bag liner which adds another 15c to the sleeping bag range. Would also recommend.

Day 1

Organizing, car rental, fuel and food stock up - that sort of thing.

Day 2

Our first hike was in Joshua Tree from the Blackrock campground. A 13km hike up over two small peaks, this was mostly our just breaking in hike.

It was a good hike with some nice views, but not too serious elevation. It turns out there wasn‚Äôt too much else from this campsite. So we moved on the next day to the park ‚Äúfor reals‚Äù and Ryan campground.

But of course, we had to take bunch of photos in the dark and the sunset. This was probably more fun than the hiking for this day üòÄ

It was cold overnight.

Day 3

After moving to our next campsite, Ryan Campground we did some hiking around a mine or something.

There were horses. This was a nicer hike deeper into the desert with more Joshua Trees (which aren‚Äôt trees). Hiking out along a dry river bed (deep sand) was ugh. Was starting to get the vibes that the desert is pretty same same at this point.

One of obligatory night time photos üëá

Was getting colder overnight, I was feeling it, but still doing ok.

Day 4

We didn‚Äôt move campsites so were able two really good hikes in. First was a short hike around a dam, although empty at the moment causes a distinct change in the flora and fauna, plus cool rocks and so on. Was pretty cool actually and our favourite hike to date.

We then had the time to do another hike and this was really good too. Had some hiking, decent elevation, abandoned mines, great rocks, some cool cacti and so on. Enjoyed this one too:

This night was really cold. I didn‚Äôt look at a thermometer, but I really felt it this time, having cold legs. Woke up to ice covering the tent. That was enough of that.

Day 5

We gave up on going to Mojave desert as we felt we‚Äôd seen the desert now, although I know they are different, we were feeling kinda done. Also we couldn‚Äôt do another night in the cold so we went to a hotel for the night and had some margarita‚Äôs.

Day 6

We took the gondola up to San Jacinto up to about 2,500m. Then we walked from there to the peak of the mountain at 3,300m over 6.5 hours.

This is so different to the desert, the heat and the fauna. It‚Äôs much drier but with tall trees everywhere and absolutely stunning views out to the Pacific at the end, this was absolutely worth it and just made the whole trip worthwhile.

We made the second tram up at 10:15am, then spoke to the super nice ranger to get our permit and then set off. But because of the time of year, we ended back at the tram just as darkness was falling. It was close.

The trail had ice bits on it where streams crossed, but overall it was clear and I didn‚Äôt need spikes at all.

It just felt so much like it‚Äôs own little ecosystem up there at 3,000m and I ‚ù§Ô∏è it. Would do again. Also the highest mountain I‚Äôve peaked (3x higher than Seymour, 1.5x higher than Mt Rohr) even though I didn‚Äôt do all the elevation in one go.

‚Äì

That‚Äôs it. Had a good trip and really enjoyed it. San Jacinto was definitely the highlight for me. Would think twice about going back, would only really be interested when its more likely to rain, because for that period the desert comes alive (apparently).
